bmiCategories.label: Underweight
bmiCategories.recommendation: Focus on nutrient-dense foods and consider consulting a healthcare provider or dietitian. Strength training can help build muscle mass.

bmiCategories.label: Healthy Weight
bmiCategories.recommendation: Maintain a balanced diet and regular exercise routine. Focus on your specific fitness goals (muscle gain, endurance, etc.).

bmiCategories.label: Overweight
bmiCategories.recommendation: Focus on creating a moderate calorie deficit through diet and increased activity. Prioritize whole foods and portion control. Resistance training is beneficial.

bmiCategories.label: Obese Class I
bmiCategories.recommendation: A more significant calorie deficit and consistent exercise are recommended. Consider consulting a healthcare provider for guidance. Focus on sustainable lifestyle changes.

bmiCategories.label: Obese Class II
bmiCategories.recommendation: Professional guidance from a healthcare provider or registered dietitian is strongly advised. Focus on gradual changes, increased daily movement, and a structured eating plan.

bmiCategories.label: Obese Class III (Severe)
bmiCategories.recommendation: Medical supervision is highly recommended. Focus on overall health improvement, mobility, and consult professionals for a safe and effective plan.

weightLossFactors: Maintain a consistent calorie deficit (consume fewer calories than you burn).
Prioritize protein intake to preserve muscle mass and aid satiety.
Increase daily physical activity, including both cardio and strength training.
Focus on whole, unprocessed foods (vegetables, fruits, lean proteins, whole grains).
Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water throughout the day.
Manage portion sizes and be mindful of calorie-dense foods and drinks.
Get adequate sleep (7-9 hours) as it affects hormones related to hunger and metabolism.
Be patient and consistent; sustainable fat loss takes time.
muscleGainTips: Consume a moderate calorie surplus (slightly more calories than you burn).
Prioritize protein intake (around 1.6-2.2g per kg of body weight) distributed throughout the day.
Engage in progressive overload strength training (gradually increasing weight, reps, or sets).
Focus on compound exercises (squats, deadlifts, bench press, rows).
Allow for adequate rest and recovery between workouts; muscles grow during rest.
Ensure sufficient carbohydrate intake to fuel workouts and replenish glycogen.
Get adequate sleep (7-9 hours) for muscle repair and hormone regulation.
Stay consistent with both training and nutrition.
cardioTips: Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity per week.
Incorporate a mix of activities you enjoy (running, cycling, swimming, brisk walking, dancing).
Include warm-ups before and cool-downs after each cardio session.
Gradually increase duration or intensity to continue improving.
Listen to your body and incorporate rest days.
Combine cardio with strength training for overall health benefits.
Maintain a balanced diet to support energy levels and recovery.
